La femme en armure a traîné Aliora en bas des escaliers et en plein soleil. À côté d'une charrette à mulets reposant sur la route poussiéreuse se tenaient deux hommes armés d'épées. Leurs plastrons brillaient du symbole de l'archi-séraphin : deux poings brisant des chaînes. À leurs pieds gisait le corps de sa mère. Il n'a pas bougé.

Un sanglot serra la gorge d'Aliora, laissant échapper un gémissement. "Rien de tout cela", dit la femme en la traînant vers la cage posée sur le chariot. Aliora fut poussée derrière les barres de fer froides, elle ne pouvait que fixer ses ravisseurs alors qu'ils s'apprêtaient à fermer la porte.
Puis elles se sont arrêtées. Les rideaux battant dans les fenêtres ouvertes de la maison se figèrent sur la brise pausée. Un oiseau en plein vol était suspendu dans l'air.

Aliora a cligné des yeux. Un homme en robe est apparu devant elle comme s'il était sorti de la brise. Il portait un masque de démon : un visage blanc, des cornes rouges et des taches de larmes noires striant des joues de porcelaine. La porte de la cage s'est ouverte sur son léger geste.

"La vie que tu connaissais a disparu", a-t-il chuchoté. Le masque n'a pas étouffé sa voix, elle venait du fond de sa tête. "Il n'y a rien que tu puisses faire à ce sujet. Vous pouvez fuir, et si vous le faites, vous fuirez toute votre vie. L'Inquisition ne cesse jamais de poursuivre."
"Ou, tu peux venir avec moi. J'ai besoin de personnes comme toi, douées de magie. Si vous souhaitez trouver un nouveau mode de vie, suivez-moi."

Il lui tendit la main. Aliora la regarda, puis le ciel morne, les inquisiteurs vêtus de rouge figés dans le temps. Elle a regardé le corps dans la poussière - sa mère, qui lui a appris à prier Empyreus, à suivre les principes de l'archi-séraphin. A croire en un monde qui croit en la justice.
Lentement, elle a tendu la main pour prendre celle de l'homme masqué.

entries.name: The Charneault Kingdom
entries: {@b LANGUAGES:} Tous les dialectes elfiques, norme impériale
{@b CURRENCY:} Armile (environ 1 couronne d'or)

Pour les non-initiés, la nation située au-delà de la forêt enchantée appelée le Labyrinthe du Bosquet semble être une terre promise de magie, de contes de fées et de beauté naturelle sans limites. Ici, les esprits de la nature peuvent encore marcher sous forme physique et communiquer avec les mortels. Pourtant, les ténèbres et la corruption se développent dans le royaume de Charneault, poussées par l'inimitié persistante entre les elfes et les hommes.

Le Royaume de Charneault couvre une vaste étendue de terres dans la partie sud-ouest d'Etharis. Son nom vient de l'elfique Caer Neiada, qui signifie "pays des mille rivières". Le Royaume s'étend du labyrinthe des bosquets au nord-est jusqu'aux Mille Fleuves au sud. Les montagnes de Rock-Teeth forment une barrière contre l'Empire de Bürach au nord.

Le Royaume de Charneault a commencé avec beaucoup de promesses. Le roi Aymeric Noblecouer a mis fin à une guerre de plusieurs générations entre humains et elfes et a apporté la paix à travers les Mille Fleuves. Aymeric a forgé le Pacte des Terres Sacrées, qui s'articulait autour de deux tâches spéciales. Le roi des elfes devait amener sa fille aînée au temple enchanté des brumes, où elle apprendrait les méthodes des chamans et aiderait à maintenir l'équilibre avec la nature. Les humains maintiendront l'ordre sur le territoire en créant des chapitres de chevaliers, des organisations fondées sur l'honneur, la vertu et le vœu de vaincre le mal. Avec cet accord en place, les deux parties ont vécu dans la paix et la prospérité.
Jusqu'à la malédiction des elfes noirs.

entries.name: The Mists
entries: Il s'agit d'une brume épaisse qui se déplace anormalement vite sur le sol ou sur l'eau, enveloppant tout ce qu'elle touche. Quelle que soit l'heure de la journée, les brumes sont toujours de la couleur du charbon, presque comme de la fumée. Là où elle passe, la lumière du soleil s'estompe, la chaleur se dissipe et les cauchemars abondent. Tous sont avertis : à la première vue des brumes sombres, fuyez.

Les brumes sombres proviennent du Temple des brumes, situé au sud du Royaume. Depuis les temps anciens, ce temple était un site sacré où de puissants druides elfes, les Bondmakers, venaient pratiquer des rituels secrets et communier avec les esprits de la nature. Ainsi, les Bondmakers maintenaient la paix entre les mortels et les esprits. Ce lien était si important que, sans faute, chacun des rois Charneault envoyait sa fille aînée au temple pour qu'elle rejoigne les faiseurs de liens, assurant ainsi la continuité des rituels.

Tout cela a changé avec l'arrivée des elfes noirs. Attisant la rancune des elfes qui estimaient que les humains avaient pris leur territoire, les elfes noirs évoquèrent la magie maléfique pour provoquer une nouvelle guerre entre les deux races. À cette fin, ils ont enlevé la fille du roi Thibault, la princesse Tiphane, et l'ont amenée au temple des brumes pour qu'elle serve de point focal à un rituel impie. Mais leurs plans ont été contrecarrés lorsque son chevalier bien-aimé, Ser Guilhem, est venu à son secours. Il a réussi à interrompre le rituel, mais la moitié d'un rituel est pire qu'un rituel complet. Une sombre malédiction a été libérée, affectant les brumes entourant le temple.

C'est ainsi que les brumes sombres ont été créées, et là où elles vont, elles créent des abominations : des monstres, des chevaliers impies et des sorciers elfes noirs qui infestent les colonies des Mille Fleuves. Quant à Ser Guilhem, la princesse Tiphaine et le sorcier Diyanthar, leurs esprits sont piégés dans les brumes sans fin, attendant leur chance de liberté.

entries.name: Charneault Kingdom
entries: {@b RULER:} Roi Thibault de Sauveterre

Le Royaume de Charneault s'est fait connaître avec la fondation du Pacte de la Terre Sacrée. La paix qu'il a instaurée entre humains et elfes a ouvert les portes de la prospérité. De grands châteaux sont apparus parmi les nombreux cours d'eau du pays, dont le plus grand est le château Lamesdhonneur, siège du gouvernement et résidence du roi actuel, Thibault de Sauveterre.

L'économie du Royaume repose sur la pêche et l'agriculture. Étant une plaine inondable, les cultures prospèrent sur le sol riche de Charneault. Bien que le poisson soit abondant, la chasse est limitée pour apaiser les esprits de la nature. Le royaume fait également du commerce avec les elfes pour le minerai des montagnes de Rock-Teeth.

Charneault est connu comme le royaume des chevaliers. Plusieurs chapitres de chevaliers célèbres ont vu le jour dans ce royaume, et ils détiennent un grand pouvoir, car les rois sont choisis parmi les maîtres de ces organisations.

Chevaliers des Templiers Sévères. Une organisation hautement militarisée qui promeut la loi et l'ordre, ils ont gagné en puissance lorsque les elfes noirs ont corrompu la brume noire et apporté la misère au pays. Depuis, ils ont ouvertement condamné la nation elfique, abhorré les serments mystiques et les liens avec la nature, et poussé à un retour à la guerre avec les elfes. La rumeur court que leur maître de chapitre, Hermand le Severe, complote pour prendre le contrôle du pays.

À l'opposé, on trouve les Gardes de Vermiel, dont les membres ont juré un devoir sacré envers les chamans elfes et les aident à maintenir la paix avec les esprits de la nature. Ceux qui s'engagent doivent croire de tout cœur à l'union entre les elfes, les humains et la nature, et être fidèles au Pacte sacré. À ce titre, seuls les chevaliers les plus vertueux et les plus dévoués sont admis au sein du chapitre. En retour, ces chevaliers obtiennent des pouvoirs extraordinaires de leurs homologues chamans.

Tous les chapitres accueillent les nouvelles candidatures dans leur organisation, mais devenir chevalier de Charneault n'est pas une mince affaire. En tant qu'écuyer, il faut revêtir armes et armure et partir en quête. Ils portent un bouclier vierge jusqu'à ce qu'ils aient accompli un acte de bravoure. Ce n'est qu'à ce moment-là qu'ils peuvent porter une armoirie signifiant leur acte. Et si un chevalier prouve suffisamment ses prouesses et sa bravoure, il peut être invité à rejoindre le conseil royal et à servir directement le roi.
Pour l'instant, le roi Thibault est préoccupé par la recherche de héros suffisamment puissants et compétents pour sauver sa fille Tiphane et Ser Guilhelm des brumes sombres.

entries.name: Tol Leyemil, City of Elves
entries: {@b RULER:} Achen Elavain

Nichée dans les contreforts sud des montagnes de Rock-Teeth, la plus ancienne cité elfique d'Etharis se dresse comme un monument à la gloire d'une race fière. Ici, on peut voir une architecture elfique qui précède même l'Empire de Bürach. Il est impossible de savoir précisément depuis combien de temps la ville existe, car les archives de Tol Leyemil sont fermées aux non-elfes. Cependant, les elfes de toutes origines et sous-races sont accueillis et acceptés ici, comme des enfants errants retournant à la maison de leurs ancêtres. C'est pourquoi Tol Leyemil a été appelée la dernière cité elfique libre, l'ultime bastion du Peuple Royal.

Tol Leyemil utilise un système de gouvernement inhabituel. La ville est dirigée par une assemblée elfique connue sous le nom d'Achen Elavain, qui est composée de membres choisis parmi la population de la ville. Bien qu'ils ne fassent pas partie du conseil, les chamans Bondmaker ont également leur mot à dire dans les décisions du gouvernement, car ils représentent la volonté de la nature elle-même.

Tol Leyemil maintient une alliance avec le royaume de Charneault, mais les relations se sont envenimées avec la malédiction des elfes noirs. L'inimitié raciale a refait surface des deux côtés, affectant les accords bilatéraux. Certains des chevaliers humains les plus radicaux ont accusé les elfes de restreindre leur approvisionnement en minerai, ce qui a eu un impact sur l'approvisionnement en armes de Charneault. Parallèlement, un nombre croissant d'elfes exigent que les humains restituent les terres qu'ils prétendent avoir été volées à leur nation. Aucune violence n'a encore éclaté entre ces deux camps, mais avec l'escalade des provocations, cela pourrait ne pas durer longtemps.

entries.name: Tol Kerdmyl
entries: Au sud-est du royaume de Charneault se trouve un lieu maudit dont personne ne s'approche : Tol Kerdwyl, la ville morte. Ici, les arbres squelettiques se nourrissent d'eaux empoisonnées, les esprits de la nature corrompus sont à leur apogée et la brume noire domine tout. Tol Kerdwyl est le bastion de Thaelkinei, la princesse liche.

Il y a des siècles, Thalkinei était une sorcière dont la beauté et le pouvoir n'avaient aucune rivale. Elle n'était pas satisfaite de cela, alors elle a cherché une magie terrible qui lui donnerait un plus grand pouvoir. Le rituel qu'elle a accompli lui a donné la capacité de commander la réalité elle-même.

Il a fallu la puissance combinée de tous les sorciers elfes pour arrêter la princesse Lich, et même là, tout ce qu'ils ont pu faire, c'est la faire tomber dans un sommeil sans fin. Bien que le monde soit à l'abri d'elle, Tol Kerdwyl reste corrompu par la magie maléfique. Seuls les monstres et les elfes noirs hantent ses forêts tordues et ses sources noires.

entries.name: Morencia
entries: {@b RULER:} Le Doge Lorenzo Flabenici et le Conseil Suprême Morencien
{@b LANGUAGES:} Norme impériale, morencienne
{@b CURRENCY:} Dima (environ 1 pièce d'or)

La cité-état de Morencia est située sur une petite île du golfe du Lion, à l'ouest des provinces de Castinellan et au sud du royaume de Charneault. Morencia a maintenu son indépendance pendant des siècles, résistant à la puissance de l'Empire de Bürach et, plus récemment, des provinces de Castinellan.

La caractéristique topographique la plus importante qui a permis cette défense sont les récifs brumeux. Enchantés il y a longtemps par les fondateurs de la ville, les récifs créent un labyrinthe aquatique que seuls les navigateurs de la guilde de la ville peuvent traverser. Cette barrière a empêché presque toutes les attaques navales de Morencia, donnant au conseil municipal un contrôle total sur ceux qui entrent et sortent de son territoire. Ainsi, les marchands entrent par le biais des guides de la guilde, restent pour un temps limité et dans un quartier spécifique, et repartent par le même chemin qu'ils sont venus.

Grâce à ses compétences en navigation et à sa puissante capacité de construction navale, Morencia a pu établir un centre commercial dont la portée s'étendait à tout le continent. Cette fortune leur a permis de créer la Guilde des banquiers, qui compte parmi ses clients les nobles et les fonctionnaires les plus puissants d'Etharis. Par la suite, l'Augustine Trading Company a établi son siège à Morencia et a acquis une participation majoritaire dans la Guilde des banquiers et le Conseil suprême.

Ceux qui cherchent à entrer dans Morencia doivent le faire avec les conseils d'un navigateur de la guilde de Morencian. Sinon, ils se perdent dans le brouillard sans fin et risquent fort de s'échouer sur un banc de sable ou de briser leur bateau contre un récif dangereux. Ceux qui parviennent à pénétrer dans la cité-état s'émerveillent de sa pléthore de canaux, de ponts, de navires, de bâtiments historiques et, bien sûr, de ses marchés regorgeant de marchandises en provenance de tout Etharis.

N'oubliez pas : Morencia n'est pas sans danger. Des rumeurs circulent selon lesquelles un culte monstrueux a pris pied dans la ville. Plus d'une nuit sans lune a vu un cadavre flotter dans les canaux, tué rituellement. Ces meurtres sont devenus si tristement célèbres qu'ils ont été surnommés la Terreur des nuits sans lune, et le conseil municipal a offert une prime à ceux qui pourraient y mettre un terme.

entries.name: Kolyhs "The Blazing Brain", Privileged Speech to the Morencian Supreme Council
entries: "Mes amis, laissez-moi vous poser une question : Quelle est la source de la grande richesse de Morencia ?"

"Commerce", diront certains d'entre vous. Mais Morencia produit peu de choses de valeur en soi. Nous sommes cinquième d'Etharis pour la pêche, quatrième pour l'artisanat et deuxième pour la production de navires. Nous n'avons pas de mines ou de terres agricoles. Toutes les armes que nous avons doivent provenir du commerce."
"Des prêts, diront certains d'entre vous. Mais d'où viennent ces énormes réserves d'or dans nos banques ?"
"Est-ce des investissements astucieux ? Un sens aigu des affaires ? Le soutien d'une guilde de marchands ? Non. Les affaires ne peuvent se faire que si vous avez quelque chose à vendre."
"Mais nous avons quelque chose à vendre, mes camarades, quelque chose que les autres nations nous prendraient si elles le pouvaient. Nous avons l'illusion de la sécurité."

"Au fil des siècles, nous avons convaincu tout Etharis que cette minuscule parcelle de terre au milieu d'un lagon était l'endroit le plus sûr pour conserver son or. Nous avons compté des rois, des membres du clergé, des hommes et des femmes de grand pouvoir parmi nos clients. Et ils nous font confiance parce qu'ils croient en une Morencia invincible. Une ville qui ne tombera jamais, dont les coffres ne seront jamais pillés par les envahisseurs."

"Notre récente victoire contre la plus puissante marine d'Etharis a cimenté cette aura d'invincibilité. Et nous ne pouvons pas nous arrêter là ! Nous devons capturer chaque espion étranger, exécuter chaque traître, repousser chaque spoliateur. Je vous le dis, à l'instant où nous perdons cette façade, notre ville est finie. Nous devons faire tout ce qui est en notre pouvoir pour maintenir l'illusion, ou nous n'avons rien."
"Aidez-moi à essayer."

entries.name: Liesech
entries: {@b RULER:} Comtesse Analita von Raiza
{@b LANGUAGES:} Norme impériale
{@b CURRENCY:} Couronne de Bürach

Liesech est une ville en crise. Autrefois centre commercial prospère et riche qui régnait sur Bite Bay, elle est rongée par une maladie mystérieuse et mortelle connue sous le nom de Weeping Pox. Malgré les efforts de l'Empire de Bürach et du Royaume de Charneault pour contenir la maladie dans la ville, le Pox s'est répandu sur leurs terres.

entries.name: Strange Tides
entries: L'ascension et la chute de Liesech ont commencé avec ses fondateurs, la famille Bouwengracht. Lorsque Liesech n'était rien de plus qu'une petite ville de pêcheurs endormie, le patriarche, Otto Bouwengracht, a rencontré une étrange entité connue sous le nom de la Gazeuse d'immondices. La créature proposa un marché à Otto : elle lui donnerait les moyens de transformer Liesech en une ville d'une richesse incommensurable, et en échange, elle serait autorisée à se nourrir de ses déchets, y compris de ses cadavres. Otto accepta, et grâce à leur contrat, Liesech commença à prospérer. En même temps, Otto a commencé un culte pour adorer et nourrir la faim sans fin de la créature.

Tirant parti de son accès à la mer et de sa situation entre Bürach et Charneault, Liesech s'est développée grâce au commerce et à l'influence culturelle. Au fil des ans, son territoire s'est étendu grâce à la construction d'un système de canaux et de fossés qui contrôlaient les inondations et aidaient sa flotte marchande. Bientôt, les navires de Liesech dominaient tout l'Etharis occidental.

La richesse qui affluait à Liesech était si grande qu'elle attira l'attention de l'Empire de Bürach, qui désirait ajouter ce joyau à sa collection. À cette fin, ils ont fait appel à un vampire captif, la comtesse Analita von Raiza, pour entrer à Liesech et utiliser ses pouvoirs pour soumettre la famille Bouwengracht à sa volonté. Grâce à leur influence, la ville se laisserait annexer par l'Empire.

Mais l'Empire avait sous-estimé le pouvoir et le désir de vengeance de la comtesse. Le jour de la célébration annuelle de la Mer nourricière, elle massacra toute la famille Bouwengracht, un crime odieux qui fut connu sous le nom de Matin rouge. Avec cela, Analita a usurpé le contrôle de la ville.

entries.name: The Battle of Bite Bay
entries: Le Gazer Filth n'en avait pas fini avec Liesech, cependant. Plutôt que de laisser la ville tomber aux mains des vampires, la créature a infecté les cadavres du Bouwengracht avec une nouvelle maladie mortelle : le Weeping Pox. En quelques jours, le Pox a infecté la population par milliers.

Comprenant qu'un seul d'entre eux pouvait contrôler la ville, Analita a ramé jusqu'au milieu du golfe afin de se débarrasser de la créature une fois pour toutes. Dans la terrible bataille qui s'ensuivit, un fort coup de vent frappa la ville, suivi d'énormes vagues qui dévastèrent le port. Après un jour, Analita est revenue, vivante mais gravement blessée.

Personne ne peut dire qui a gagné le duel ou si le Filth Gazer existe toujours. Quant à la Comtesse, elle s'est barricadée dans le Haut Beffroi au centre de la ville et n'a pas été revue depuis. Son Culte de la Dame Noire s'occupe d'elle et gère ses affaires dans la ville.

Pendant ce temps, la vérole pleureuse incontrôlée a ravagé Liesech. Bien qu'il s'agisse d'un nouveau territoire, Bürach ne peut rien faire pour les citoyens et bloque tous les chemins vers Liesech. Malheureusement, il était quelques jours trop tard : la peste se répandait également dans l'Empire.

Liesech est en train de mourir. Non seulement elle est encore sous le choc de la Variole, mais la quarantaine imposée par Bürach a décimé son économie. Actuellement, la seule faction capable de traiter la variole est le Morbus Doctore. Cependant, cette organisation sectaire est plus encline aux expériences torturantes et demandera sûrement un prix élevé pour un traitement. Le conseil municipal de Liesech continue de chercher de l'aide auprès de toutes les âmes bienveillantes désireuses de sauver leur ville.

entries.name: Languages in Etharis
entries: Les langues d'Etharis divisent le monde autant que les frontières politiques. Les citoyens ordinaires d'Etharis parlent la langue de leur nation, et rarement autre chose. Seuls ceux qui voyagent beaucoup ont le besoin ou les moyens de parler une autre langue que celle de leur village et de leurs voisins.

Les races ont également leur propre langue, mais même dans ce cas, elles ne sont apprises et parlées que si elles sont la langue prédominante dans une région. Les familles naines établies dans une des nations comme Ostoya, par exemple, ne parleront jamais le nain, préférant l'Ostoy. Les centres raciaux au sein d'une nation, cependant, parleront certainement à la fois la langue raciale et la langue raciale.

Comme il n'existe pas de langue commune qui unisse le monde civilisé, les traducteurs sont très appréciés et respectés. Les aventuriers, ainsi que ceux qui gagnent leur vie en se déplaçant d'un endroit à l'autre, prennent souvent le temps d'apprendre autant de langues qu'ils le peuvent.
Les langues suivantes sont les plus utilisées à Etharis :

items.name: Charneault:
entries: La langue dominante du Royaume de Charneault.

items.name: Castinellan:
entries: La langue dominante des provinces de Castinellan. Cette langue est également utilisée pour la plupart des textes religieux d'Etharis. Jusqu'à récemment, traduire les enseignements des séraphins dans une autre langue que le castinellan était considéré comme un crime. Le castinellan est aussi majoritairement parlé en Morencia, ce qui en fait la langue la plus utilisée dans le commerce.

items.name: Valiki:
entries: La langue dominante des clans Valikan. Chacun des clans parle un dialecte légèrement différent du Valiki, mais chaque dialecte est suffisamment similaire pour se faire comprendre.

items.name: Ostoy:
entries: La langue dominante d'Ostoya

items.name: Lower Bürach:
entries: Le dialecte des roturiers de l'Empire du Bürach. Il est plus fortement accentué que le Bürach supérieur, ce qui rend la population générale de la nation plus difficile à comprendre pour les étrangers.

items.name: Higher Bürach:
entries: Le dialecte de haute naissance dans l'Empire de Bürach. La plupart des écrits officiels sont également rédigés dans ce dialecte, comme les textes religieux, les lois, les décrets royaux, les pièces de théâtre et les poèmes, etc. Si un étranger apprend le Bürach, c'est ce dialecte qu'il apprend.

data.name: Magic of Etharis
entries: À Etharis, le terme "magie" est un terme fourre-tout pour désigner un pouvoir qui échappe aux capacités des mortels, un moyen de modifier la réalité. En réalité, il existe trois formes distinctes de magie, chacune ayant ses propres sources mystiques : arcane, divine et naturelle.

entries.name: On Magical Theory
entries: Le mage dans son école, le sorcier voyageur dans sa quête, l'archimage dans son sanctuaire - tous ces personnages s'appuient sur une force latente qui existe partout dans Etharis, un pouvoir qu'ils appellent magie. Pourtant, malgré le nombre incalculable de livres écrits sur le sujet, la source de ce pouvoir n'est pas très bien comprise.

La plus grande autorité sur la nature de la magie des arcanes était de loin un homme nommé Raakan el-Adakar. Archimage ayant vécu au début de l'Age d'expansion, Raakan a constitué une impressionnante bibliothèque sur la nature et les origines de la magie.

Il fut le premier à déterminer que la magie des arcanes émanait d'une dimension parallèle au plan matériel, un lieu imprégné d'une énergie latente qui pouvait altérer la réalité. Il a nommé ce plan Numena et l'énergie elle-même "numen". La magie, selon Raakan, consiste simplement à utiliser le numen pour donner une forme physique à la volonté du magicien.

D'après ses recherches, lorsque les mages lancent des sorts, ils affaiblissent légèrement la frontière qui sépare Numena du plan matériel afin d'attirer le numen. Comme une loupe qui focalise un rayon de soleil, ils transforment le numen en l'effet magique de leur choix.

Plusieurs théories ont été avancées sur ce qu'est réellement Numena. L'une d'elles affirme qu'il s'agit de la demeure originelle des dieux et de la source de leur pouvoir. Une autre dit que Numena est lui-même une entité vivante qui tente de façonner notre dimension pour qu'elle corresponde à la sienne.

Malheureusement, Raakan n'a pas vécu pour profiter des fruits de son travail. Pour sa dernière expérience magique, il a ouvert un portail lui permettant d'entrer physiquement dans le royaume de Numena. Il est revenu par ce portail cinq ans plus tard, complètement fou et parlant une langue inconnue. Il a passé ses derniers jours enfermé dans le donjon de Coldiron.

entries.name: Colleges of Magic
entries: Une capacité aussi potentiellement dangereuse que la magie est maintenue sous contrôle par certaines autorités, et les utilisateurs de magie qui fréquentent un collège ont depuis longtemps appris à respecter cette hiérarchie.

entries.name: Erlefurt Colleges
entries: Le Nordenland de l'Ouest est le centre d'apprentissage des arcanes de l'Empire de Bürach, et il tient à le rester. La capitale Erlefurt compte le plus grand nombre de collèges magiques du continent, le collège Magister étant le plus ancien et le plus vénérable de tous.

Il est difficile pour un aspirant mage d'entrer dans un collège d'Erlefurt, mais le collège Magister se montre exceptionnellement rigoureux. Le Magister ne choisit que les meilleurs parmi ses candidats - pas seulement ceux qui ont de grandes aptitudes magiques, mais aussi ceux qui sont les plus susceptibles de faire honneur à l'école.

Les collèges d'Erlefurt considèrent la magie comme une force qui doit être maîtrisée avec sagesse, le genre de sagesse que seuls ceux qui sont formés à la manière des mages d'Erlefurt possèdent. En tant que tel, tous les étudiants doivent jurer de suivre un ensemble de lois rigides, énumérées dans un tome appelé le Codex du magicien.
Les principales lois du Codex sont les suivantes :
Seuls les sorciers qui réussissent les épreuves finales des collèges d'Erlefurt peuvent porter le titre de mage d'Erlefurt.
Un mage d'Erlefurt doit défendre son collège contre tous ceux qui voudraient le spolier ou voler ses secrets.
Seuls les collèges d'Erlefurt peuvent former un étudiant. Tous les étudiants doivent être inscrits et approuvés par les Collèges.
Toutes les expériences magiques doivent être enregistrées et approuvées par les collèges.

Tout sorcier d'Erlefurt qui enfreint ce code de lois est pourchassé par les Enforcers, un groupe d'abjurateurs d'élite très doués pour maîtriser l'un des leurs. Une fois capturés, ils sont emmenés au tribunal des magiciens et jugés par le Grand Mage. S'ils sont reconnus coupables, les transgresseurs peuvent être emprisonnés magiquement ou même exécutés. Quant aux autres institutions arcaniques qui ne souscrivent pas à ces principes, elles sont traitées avec mépris, voire avec une franche hostilité.
Comme il n'y a pas d'écoles de magie établies dans le Grarjord, les clans Valikan envoient des étudiants prometteurs à Erlefurt pour qu'ils y reçoivent une formation.

entries.name: Ravencourt Sanctuary
entries: A l'est des côtes de Raevo, caché dans les brumes de son île enchantée, le Sanctuaire de Ravencourt forme ses mages dans sa propre académie.

Contrairement à son rival, le Magister College, le Sanctuaire croit que la magie ne peut se développer que par la liberté. Ainsi, le Sanctuaire de Ravencourt a peu de lois pour guider les actions de ses mages. Leur règle principale est que les mages doivent garder tous les secrets du Sanctuaire en sécurité. En dehors de cela, un mage qui obtient un diplôme du Sanctuaire est libre de faire ce qu'il veut et d'enseigner à qui il veut.

Malgré leur apparente absence de lois, la punition pour avoir enfreint la règle principale est à la fois sévère et sans équivoque. Avant de quitter le Sanctuaire, un sorcier de Ravencourt fait le vœu de protéger les secrets de son académie. Il écrit son nom sur une page d'un livre enchanté et y dépose une goutte de son sang. Cela crée une malédiction très puissante : s'il rompt son vœu, la page se détache du livre et brûle. Le magicien meurt alors d'une mort indescriptible.

En raison de la politique de l'époque, les mages d'Erlefurt et du Sanctuaire de Ravencourt sont techniquement en guerre. Les mages des deux camps ont l'ordre permanent de s'anéantir mutuellement à vue, bien que cela soit rarement pratiqué.

entries.name: Sarmar Academy
entries: Ayant vécu des milliers d'années en tant que peuple, les elfes ne sont pas des débutants en matière de magie. Dans leur capitale, Tol Leyemil, ils ont créé leur propre collège de sorciers : L'Académie Sarmar, célèbre pour ses abjurateurs, ses mystiques et ses mages de guerre.

Les mages Sarmar croient que la magie s'apprend et se contrôle par une observation attentive. C'est en observant et en écoutant le monde naturel que les elfes ont appris à invoquer et à façonner le numen. Ils enseignent donc à leurs élèves à faire très attention aux détails et à se concentrer sur ce qu'ils peuvent sentir. L'accent mis sur la patience rend l'enseignement lent. Souvent, l'éducation à Sarmar peut durer des décennies. Pour les elfes, bien sûr, c'est une courte période de temps.

La ville étant entièrement elfique, seuls les elfes peuvent s'inscrire à l'Académie de Sarmar proprement dite. L'exception est la Maison Aemanyir, une branche de l'Académie située en dehors des limites de la ville. Ce programme a été lancé il y a plusieurs dizaines d'années par un mage elfique nommé Alren Corynthios, afin d'enseigner la magie elfique à des non-elfes. La plupart des académiciens de Sarmar considèrent que c'est une perte de temps, mais la persistance d'Alren et ses relations avec la noblesse elfique ont permis à l'école de continuer à fonctionner pendant de nombreuses années, même si c'est à peine.

entries.name: Renegade Colleges
entries: Il existe plusieurs collèges non reconnus à Etharis qui prétendent enseigner la magie. Comme ils ont tendance à produire des mages de qualité inférieure, ils sont regardés avec mépris par les collèges établis. Au pire, ils sont considérés comme des sources potentielles de mésaventures magiques, car sans conseils appropriés, ces mages peuvent causer des dommages irréparables à la réputation de tous les mages - ou pire, provoquer une catastrophe magique.

Les sorciers d'Erlefurt ont pour protocole de capturer tout sorcier "renégat" et de l'amener à Erlefurt pour traitement et éventuellement rééducation. Ceux qui refusent cette demande polie sont considérés comme des combattants ennemis.

entries.name: Societal Mistrust
entries: La société est divisée dans sa vision de la magie des arcanes. Dans l'Empire de Bürach, par exemple, elle était considérée comme un moyen de maintenir l'ordre, de projeter le pouvoir, d'inculquer l'obéissance, de recueillir des informations et de maintenir le statu quo.

Cependant, avec l'arrivée de la Grande Bête, la magie est désormais traitée avec plus de suspicion, car certains en sont venus à soupçonner que l'entité était le résultat d'une expérience arcanique qui aurait mal tourné. Les Gardiens du Cœur n'ont pas nié cette notion, car cela leur permet de ne pas être coupables de cette affaire.

L'opinion des Ostoyens sur la magie est plus variée. Dans la province de Soma, les classes inférieures craignent la magie comme quelque chose qu'elles sont incapables de comprendre. Elles s'en tiennent également à l'écart pour éviter de susciter la jalousie et l'ire de la noblesse. La Cour cramoisie estime que l'utilisation de la magie lui revient de droit ; toute autre personne qui l'utilise doit soit devenir son serviteur, soit être détruite en tant que menace potentielle. Ainsi, on trouve souvent des mages à leur service dans leur guerre contre Raevo et l'Empire de Bürach.

Dans la province de Raevo, la magie fait partie intégrante de la vie quotidienne. Les ateliers et les marchés de Castalore regorgent de sorciers et de constructions magiques, le tout sous l'œil vigilant du Sanctuaire de Ravencroft.

Dans le royaume de Charneault, les elfes considèrent la magie comme une partie intégrante de leur vie. Ils tiennent les mages qualifiés en haute estime, même s'ils mettent en garde contre le coût de la recherche d'un plus grand pouvoir magique.

Les elfes noirs n'ont pas cette retenue ; ils sondent les secrets les plus profonds de la magie sans se soucier des dangers qu'ils encourent. S'ils ont atteint un grand pouvoir, le prix à payer est souvent celui de l'ensemble du royaume, comme c'est le cas pour la Brume noire.

In the human-controlled lands of the Charneault, attitudes vary greatly. Mages are treated with respect in more learned circles, but among Knight Chapters they are treated with suspicion, and in the case of the Severe Templars, outright hostility. They hold elven magic accountable for the suffering endured by the populace and forego all arcane abilities in favor of strength in arms and divine fervor.

It is worth noting the Castinellan Provinces in particular when it comes to magic for the specific chance they've chosen: deplorably, the theocracy is hostile to all forms of arcane magic. It is the will of Empyreus, they claim, that their people wage a righteous war against all magic-users and those who harbor them. To undertake this task, the Arcanist Inquisition has assembled a host of knights and common soldiers under the command of clerics and paladins. Backed by the power of belief, they call on divine magic to locate arcane mages and neutralise them.

As such, magic-users must all be careful when entering the Castinellan Provinces, lest they be arrested, imprisoned, and very likely put to death by the Arcanist Inquisition. Mages cannot even expect sympathy from the common folk; most peasants hold all magic as witchcraft and devilry, the power of demons brought to Etharis.

The Castinellans have yet to move against nations that employ magic, such as the Bürach and the Charneault Kingdom. But should the theocracy grow more powerful, a "righteous war" would certainly be in the cards.

entries.name: The Brothers Part 3
entries: "It can't be."

Mischa gazed at the staff in his hand as he stood with the rest of the Sanctuary's mages. Today was their final day, their graduation. Their crystal staff would glow when it was time for their departure.
Only his did not light up.
"You've been chosen to remain," the Keeper whispered in his mind. "One life for the knowledge you've all attained."
"No," Mischa said. But his classmates were already teleporting away, nodding to him in commiseration. They left him alone all the same.
"I refuse!" Mischa shouted. "It can't be me! It can't!" His brother's face drifted through his mind. He dropped his staff, ready to fight or flee.
The Keeper appeared before him, wrapped in robes and silence. He raised a skeletal hand. "What binds you to the outside world?"
Mischa gasped as memories invaded his mind. The death of his parents. The burning of Kolyat. The screams. It was all too much—he fell to his knees in horror.

The Keeper lowered his hand. "I have chosen well." After a pause, the Keeper continued. "I have an offer. Stay five more years, and you will have all the knowledge and power you desire. What do you say?"
Mischa gazed into the dark void of the Keeper's hood. "Why help me?"
The Keeper said nothing, but Mischa believed he was smiling.
{@b To be Continued...}

entries.name: The Aetheric War and the Gods' End
entries: At the start of the Age of Antiquity, the gods came into being. They opened their eyes to behold a universe of wonder and chaos, and they were enamored by it. They wanted to shape it into something that resembled them. But to do that, they needed to impose order.

The gods, good and evil alike, banded together to form a pantheon. They shaped the firmament and the seas, then the land and all the creatures that followed. They named the land Etharis and created the races to populate it.

As these newborn mortals turned their minds to their creators, the gods found an endless font of believers. Their worship lifted the gods to greater heights, securing their ability to turn the wheel of the universe.

But the gods were not alone. At the fringes of their ordered realm lurked the Aether Kindred—incomprehensible beings of pure chaos who predated the gods themselves. The Kindred were mostly content to remain uninvolved, thought occasionally the gods would find a piece of reality in disarray—a star gone missing, an ocean dried up, an entire city disappearing into the void.

When the entire race of the Sommerkin vanished one day, the gods decided they'd had enough. The Aether Kindred were an active threat to their power. The gods feared that one day all they had built would be stripped away. They need to strike now, while they still had the faith of their followers and stood at the height of their powers.
Thus, all the gods, good and evil alike, banded together as a host and launched an assault on the Kindred. This became known as the Aetheric War.

None can say precisely what happened to the gods who participated in the war. Some historians say it was a slaughter. Others believe the gods were consumed by the eldritch horrors they tried to defeat. Others state that some gods retreated from this plane to someplace the Kindred could not reach them. While nothing is certain about what happened to the gods thereafter, it is quite certain they were utterly defeated.

Of the great pantheon, only the four youngest survived: Galt the Builder, Maligant Warclad, Ulmyr the Wise, and Aurelia of the Hearth. Perhaps out of caution or fear, they held back from the Aetheric War. Thus, they were the only ones left to pick up the pieces, becoming responsible for the fostering of Etharis's future.

If there was any silver lining to the Aetheric War, it was that the Kindred never showed themselves afterward. It's believed these horrors slept deeply after destroying so many of the gods, perhaps requiring rest to heal from their wounds. But once they have regenerated, they will likely take revenge on the rest of the gods' creations.

Whatever the reason, this left the Four Divines to their own devices. As the surviving gods left to guide the mortals of Etharis, they decided to band together. Their idea was to create an ideal empire, the "one above all" to act as a shining beacon for all mortals to emulate. This idea became the Bürach Empire. Its first emperor, Indorius I, would be the lightbringer for all the nations of Etharis. To this end, the Four Divines gifted him with four holy artifacts that would enable him to rule wisely and protect his empire.

For a time, all was good. Unfortunately, this method of salvation carried the seeds of its own destruction. The Bürach Empire so loved their emperor that they decided to keep his bloodline eternally pure. The Church of the Hearthkeepers imposed the Edict of Eternal Blood, mandating that only those of the line of Indorius I may ascend to the throne. With that, they forced his descendants to intermarry, weakening their blood. The wretched outcome of this practice finally manifested in the Mad Emperor, Leopold.

When Leopold touched the divine artifacts, his mind and soul were instantly connected with the Four Divines—and it drove them all to madness. Galt, Malignant, Ulmyr, and Aurelia warred among themselves, each vying to reign as the One True God of the universe. This culminated in the Gods' End, when these last remaining deities destroyed one another.
Etharis carries on as a godless world. While divine power remains, it constitutes but a shadow of its former glory.

entries.name: Arch Seraphs and Arch Daemons
entries: In the absence of the gods, Arch Seraphs and Arch Daemons took up their mantle. While these beings are lesser divinities, they inherited part of their deity's power, making them the source of divine magic in Etharis.
The Arch Seraphs each correspond to a virtue.

rows: The Arch Seraph of Valor is the former servant of the war god Maligant. A favorite of holy warriors, he is the patron of courage and strength, as well as all who seek to wage a righteous war. Due to his uncompromising nature, his followers tend to become zealots in the pursuit of righteousness. Empyreus is traditionally opposed by the Lord of Fear, Beleth. Although of late, Beleth seems to have gotten the better of him, as some of Empyreus's followers have tended to use terror to enforce their beliefs.

The Arch Seraph of Truth was once the librarian of the goddess Typharia. Zabriel abandoned his mistress's neutral stance and instead sought to bring an end to the lies that support tyrants and oppressors. He is loved by scholars and truth seekers, and he is opposed directly by Venin, the Great Deceiver.

The Arch Seraph of Temperance holds sway over the domains of peace and spirituality. A patron of monks, clerics, and peacemakers, Aphaelon is honored by those who seek enlightenment. Once a servant of Myria, goddess of joy, he has since decided there is little joy to be found in Etharis, and he has therefore taken to becoming the saint of those who seek spiritual balance. Those who follow his ways find freedom from addictions and worldly desires. He is opposed by the Arch Daemon of Hedonism, Sitri.

entries: The Arch Seraph of Justice, she has remained faithful to the ways of her former master and seeks to destroy the Aether Kindred who killed him. She is the patron of good judges, vigilantes, and hunters of eldritch abominations. She often foils the schemes of Gorodyn, the Daemon of Avarice.
While she is known as the Great Judge, Solyma has gained another epitaph from her worshippers in Ostoya: Lady Vengeance. The bloodiest family vendettas have thus been waged in her name.

rows: The Arch Seraph of Sacrifice holds power over the domains of Heroism and Compassion. Unlike the other archangels, he is actually an aspect of his former mistress Vetara, the goddess of love. He is the patron of martyrs and those who aspire to be great heroes. He represents hope for a better tomorrow that comes by making sacrifices, both great and small. He offers strength to those who must surrender themselves for a great cause. He is opposed by Malikir the Proud.

entries: The Arch Seraph of Mercy, her domain is healing and freedom from suffering. She does not have the power of Aurelia, goddess of protection; she can only offer aid to those already sick, wounded, or in distress. It is said that this new dark age offers no rest for Miklas the Merciful. She is opposed by Tormach, the new Lord of War.
The Arch Daemons each correspond to the cardinal sins. None have remained faithful to their erstwhile masters.

The Arch Daemon of Fear goes by other names: the Trickster, the Laughing Man, and Blackjester. Beleth's goal is to spread fear throughout the world, and in this regard he has far surpassed his former master. Beleth derives pleasure from torturing mortals with their worst fears. He's the patron of tyrants and oppressors everywhere, but Beleth's cruel practical joke is that every one of these people end up fearing the very people they oppress. To him, it's eternally funny.
Beleth has no fear of Empyreus, and any who mentions the Arch Seraphs causes Blackjester to smirk, as if from a private joke.

rows: The Arch Daemon of Deceit is known as the Great Deceiver, Dusktongue, and Hooded. She is the master of illusion, lies, and insanity. Venin is capable of giving her followers power over illusions and deceit, but eventually even they lose track of what is truth and fiction. Venin hates Zabriel and rewards those who assassinate the Arch Seraph's followers.

The Arch Daemon of Hedonism, who is also called Bloodrose and the Tempter, lures mortals to give in to gluttony, lust, and the basest worldly desires. Those who follow Sitri eventually lose themselves to their addictions. Sitri's most prized possessions are the souls of Aphaelon's followers who backslide into their desires. Sitri enjoys taunting the Arch Seraph with these mortals the most.

entries: The Arch Daemon of Avarice is often called the King of Red Coins. He's a corrupted follower of Jezra, god of commerce. In his boundless treasury, he counts the souls of those who have given themselves to hoarding wealth by whatever means necessary, leaving hunger and poverty for the rest of the world.
Gorodyn fears Solyma, as he owns so much there is very little he can do to defend it all. He has taken to bribing mortals and other beings to fight her in his stead.

The Arch Daemon of Pride prefers the title "God". As the most powerful of the Arch Daemons, her domain is tyranny and the abuse of authority. She is known to corrupt heroes who start out as goodhearted but eventually give in to pride. Inevitably, her followers meet a terrible fall.
Malikir considers her counterpart, Morael, as a weakling and not even worth mentioning.

The Arch Daemon of Wrath goes by names such as Manslayer and Marauder, as he has taken over the domain of the war god Maligant. He is a patron and source of strength for evil-aligned warriors. Unfortunately, he cannot offer strategy or wisdom, only mindless butchery and violence. For Tormach, winning comes second to dealing as much suffering and death as possible. Privately, even the other Arch Daemons consider him the weakest of their number.
Though he has tried time and again, Tormach has failed to defeat Miklas the Redeemer, a fact that infuriates him to no end.

entries.name: Playing a Cleric or Paladin
entries: The gods' presence has waned. Divine power is rare in Etharis. As a cleric or a paladin, you are a rarity, and your patron calls upon you to project their power into this world.

Remember that Etharis has entered into a Dark Age, the likes of which has never been experienced. Its people are starved for guidance and want to believe in a power greater than themselves. As a wielder of divine magic, you may use that hunger to bring hope and light to the world, or you could twist it to your advantage. Rarity is a form of power, after all.

entries.name: Gormadraug, the Prismatic Wyrm
entries: In the beginning, when the gods created the world, they had no idea of the power they would imbue into it: it was, after all, their first attempt at creation. Thus they imparted too much of their power into the substances they made and accidentally breathed life into. This act is how the Primordials came to be.

Chief of the Primordials is a being known as Gormadraug, a tiny being that carried a spark of the gods' divinity. Gormadrag amused the gods so they kept it as a pet. Over time, their treatment became abusive, using Gormadraug for hunting sport, slaying and resurrecting him over and over. Finally, when they tired of him, they abandoned him on the newly formed Etharis.

For millennia, Gormadraug devoured everything he could see: rocks, ice, lava, and air. With every century, he grew larger, until finally, he emerged as a colossal Wyrm with power over all the elements. So powerful was he that could spawn his own children, themselves powerful Primordials.

However, he never forgot his treatment at the hands of the gods. He nursed his hatred for a millennia. The final straw was when the gods declared that the new race of mortals would inherit all of Etharis. Gormadraug sought his revenge by sending his Primordials to war against the gods.
Despite his numerous spawn, they were not powerful or plentiful enough to achieve his goal. The gods handily defeated the Primordials. Gormadraug survived, however, and went into hiding.

This setback did have one upside for the Great Wyrm: it emboldened the gods to believe they could fight the Aether Kindred as well. The debacle that followed left Etharis with only four remaining gods.

Gormadraug wasted no time: he created four new spawn that he would use to fight a new war on the gods and their mortal children. These Primordials were Alondo of the Deep, Morrakesh the Burning Lady, Citrolach the Living Mountain, and Ilhara the Queen of Air and Shadow.

This time, Gormadraug aimed to win. He became as cruel to his children as the gods were to him. To strengthen them, he forced them to compete with each other endlessly, killing each other in an arena of death and resurrection.

The four Primordials endured centuries of this treatment, each one aching to be free of their sire. They found their opportunity from an unexpected source: a man named Kentigern and his six companions, seeking to tame the northern wilderness for habitation.

Alondo convinced his siblings to betray their sire and take the adventurers under their wing. Morrakesh and Citrolach formed powerful magic weapons that could pierce Gormadraug's flesh. Ilhara composed for them a magic song that would put the Wyrm to sleep. Alondo taught them enchantments that would keep them alive, and he also told them where to strike Gormadraug's heart.

Thus, Kentigern and his companions were able to slay Gormadraug. His body was destroyed, save for his indestructible heart, which was thrown into the northern sea and formed an island. Subsequently, the four Primordials divided Etharis among themselves and formed their own realms. Citrolach and Morrakesh settled along the equator, while Alondo and Ilhara resided closer to the poles.

Yet all four Primordials know that their sire had not truly perished, but merely slumbered in a state of hibernation. Even now, mortals obtain command over the elements from the Prismatic Wyrm. The day may come when Gormadraug would awaken and wreak his vengeance across Etharis. They continually seek ways to prevent this from happening. Yet with the appearance of coldfire, it seems the Prismatic Wyrm's resurrection is coming ever closer.

entries.name: Lady Morrakesh
entries: The Burning Lady, Red Queen, and Emberheart are among her many names. The Primordial of fire holds court in her dimension of Flamebourne. She commands azers, efreeti, and fire giants in her army.

Morrakesh suffered the worst under Gormadraug, as the Wyrm saw her as his most destructive weapon. As such she is highly capricious and easy to anger; she may reward you with great riches as easily as she can turn you into a cinder. Great care must be taken in petitioning her.
Those who would summon Morrakesh for favors must first burn a sentient being alive as a sacrifice.

entries.name: Alondo
entries: Lord of the Deep and ruler of the Endless Sea, Alondo controls the denizens of lakes and seas. He is worshipped by merfolk, water elementals, and the mighty leviathans.

Aside from Kentigern, Alondo has no love for mortals and wishes to be left alone. That said, he is the most conscientious of his ilk, working diligently to prevent the return of Gormadraug. Still, rumours persist that he has something to do with the outbreak of coldfire plaguing Etharis.
Those who would invoke Alondo must first slay one of his hated enemies and hurl its heart into the sea.

entries.name: Citrolach
entries: The Living Mountain masters over all those who pledge themselves to earth and stone: earth elementals, deep dwarves, and gnomes, as well as all who dwell in his underground realm of Stonereach. His power extends to plants and the denizens of the forests.

To summon Citrolach, one must surrender a fortune in gems and gold, all of which is returned by the Primordial to the ground from where it was taken. Take care, however. Notoriously stubborn, Citrolach holds to a particular stand for centuries. The saying goes that it is easier to move a mountain than convince Citrolach to change his mind.

entries.name: Ilhara
entries: The Queen of Air and Shadow is the most ambitious Primordial of all. She sends her army of djinn, sylphs, and air elementals abroad to find secrets from among mortals and spirits alike. Her ultimate aim is to be powerful enough to fill the void left by the dead gods.
Ilhara requires that a dark secret be whispered into the air before she can be summoned.

entries.name: Gormadraug
entries: The Great Prismatic Wyrm is also a powerful source of nature magic, though he doesn't know this in his current state. There is no known way to invoke him. Moreover, worship of the Wyrm is illegal throughout the Valikan Clans. The Primordials also warn that drawing power from Gormadraug may even awaken him, and readily smites any druids or rangers who try.

entries.name: Playing a Druid or Ranger in Etharis
entries: There are three important centers in Etharis for learning nature magic: the druid circles of the Valikan Clans, the Order of the Golden Bough in Eastern Nordenland, and the elves of Tol Leyemil. These are not the only places for learning, but druids and rangers that emerge from here are considered to be among the elite.

your power is derived from the Primordials—including Gormadraug. These beings have taken over the realm of gods in terms of nature magic. They each serve their own interests and are not bound by mortal notions of good and evil. They are, however, hostile to all that threatens that power. This includes the possible awakening of Gormadraug, the corruption of nature caused by the Dark Mist, and the arrival of the Great Beast. The Primordials require druids and rangers alike to fight these forces wherever they encounter them.

data.name: New Subclasses
entries: Adventurers specialize in their abilities and outlooks based on the culture in which they train and advance. Characters in the world of Etharis are influenced by dark and sometimes malevolent powers, delving into areas others might avoid.

The subclasses here reflect back onto the heroes the world in which they live and fight. Some absorb into themselves the dangerous but powerful forces they fight. What that acceptance of terrible power means on the psyches of the adventurers can be varied; however, one cannot deny that delving into the darkness to find strength often comes at a steep and sometimes fatal cost.

As you play with these subclasses, reflect on how the common folk that the characters interact with accept and react to them. Are these powers visible to bystanders when they are used? If so, do they mimic or even outright exemplify the types of powers used by the monsters that the commoners fear?
Subclasses presented in this chapter can be found in the {@filter Classes|classes|source=GHPG} page.

entries.name: The Brothers Part 4
entries: "You can't win."
Surprised, Laszlo nearly didn't catch the next sword blow with his shield. "Yes I can!" he shouted, raising his sword.
His sparring partner, Major Wingard, deflected his strike. "You can't win unless you're giving your all, which you aren't."
Laszlo fought harder. Yet with every blow from his master, he was forced to give ground.
"You have yet to surrender your might and will to a cause," Wingard continued. "And without a great cause, you're no match for a powerful enemy."
Roaring, Laszlo slammed his shield against her breastplate. Wingard fell to the floor, and Laszlo's sword found her throat. "Yield," he growled.
The Major lashed out with her foot. There was a crunch as Lazlo's ankle buckled. Agony shot up his leg, and he hit the ground with a cry.

"I'm neither stronger nor faster than you," Wingard said, picking herself up. "What I have is a great cause. My mind and body are one. I acknowledge no defeat. I feel no fear.Tell me now, if you have a great cause of your own."
Gritting teeth, Laszlo cried, "I will purge Ostoya of all undead!"
Magic coursed through his body, and the pain vanished as his bones knit back together.
"Arise, knight," said Wingard. "Welcome to the Order of Dawn."
{@b To be Continued...}

entries.name: The Brothers Part 5
entries: Is there no other way?"
Mischa stood before the Black Tome, a book of rituals for the darkest forms of magic. Across the table, the Keeper shifted in his voluminous robes.
"There are many ways," the mage intoned. "All of them doomed to failure. You seek revenge against a vampire lord, do you not?"
"Yes but—"
""An immensely powerful creature who commands a horde of undead. Do you think you can defeat him as you are? What other being can challenge him—except a lich?"
Mischa could not reply.
"The path to lichdom is exceedingly harsh. You must tear your soul from your body and place it in a phylactery. And the only way to do so..."
The Keeper stood and drifted closer. "But if you prefer your moral code, if you'd rather retreat to your seasonless world with your quest unfulfilled, then leave the book. Abandon your vow."
A skeletal hand reached out for the tome, but Mischa snatched it away.
"I am an Ostoyan. My vengeance is forever."
"Then you know the price." The voice was filled with satisfaction. "Raise an army worthy of the dark. And kill that which is dearest to your heart."
{@b To be Continued...}

entries.name: The Brothers Part 6
entries: "There's nothing to be done," said Lt. Galvek.
Laszlo stared out over the wooden walls at the mother and child running for the safety of the fort. Close at their heels was the encroaching zombie horde, hands and teeth ready to rend their flesh.
"We can't operate the gate fast enough," Galvek reiterated. "If we try, the zombies will come swarming in and kill the townsfolk in the fort. We can't save everyone. There is no way."

Laszlo gave him a hard stare. "There's always a way." He drew his sword and shouted, "Open the gates! Warriors of the Order, follow me!" With that, he leaped down from the palisades to come between the woman and the zombies. His squad followed.
Together, with swords and arrows and divine power, they held off the horde long enough for the heavy gates to open, offering them all a retreat.
The mother and child were saved. But when Laszlo turned to the eight knights who followed him, he saw only three had returned alive.
When Major Wingard led the Order to rescue the people in the fort, she found Laszlo with his head in his hands, in tears.
{@b To be Continued...}

entries.name: The Brothers Part 7
entries: Laszlo stared, thunderstruck, at the report in his hands. "This must be a mistake. This is impossible."

"I'm afraid it's true," replied Magroch. The Order's spymaster rarely had to defend information he'd already verified; if he said something was true, it was. "The necromancer responsible for last month's zombie attack is your brother, Mischa. Grash, his fellow student from the Ravencourt Sanctuary, identified him."

Laszlo looked down at the report with unbelieving eyes. His younger brother, whom he once had to lift up in order to pick fruits from a bough. Dear, sentimental Mischa, who had sworn an oath to Solyma herself.
Laszlo lifted his eyes to Major Wingard. The woman gazed back from her place by the window. "I know it's hard for you. I'll send Miriam to handle the matter. She'll bear Answerer—"
Laszlo's blood ran cold. "No. He is my brother. I will go."
Magroch and Wingard exchanged a look, but the Major nodded and opened the chest next to her, retrieving their holy sword, Answerer.
Accepting the artifact, Laszlo said, "I swear, I will redeem him,"
"Not with a sword" was Wingard's reply.
{@b To be Continued...}

entries.name: The Brothers Part 8
entries: "Brother..."

Seeing Laszlo remove his helm, Mischa marveled at how little he'd changed. Still that gentle face and noble gaze. For a moment, Mischa felt his resolve waver. Then he recalled the flames consuming his home, and his hatred roared back to life.
"I didn't want to believe it," Laszlo said, gazing up at the zombie soldiers manning the fortress walls.
"I was hoping someone else would come," Mischa remarked, "but of course it would be you. How the fates despise us."
"Why, brother?"
"I made a vow."
"Don't hide behind your damn vow! None of this was necessary! You didn't have—"
"Yes, I did. That's the difference between us, Laszlo. I knew that to achieve anything, one needs power. Which is what I have."
"This is not you, brother."
"Isn't it?" Mischa's eyes narrowed. "What of you, Laszlo? Have you forgotten our vow, our revenge? Why haven't you faced the Count? Why fight instead for peasants and townsfolk?"
"We were those people once, Mischa!"
"But no more." Mischa's eyes glowed poisonous green. "Will you aid me now, brother? Will you join me in fulfilling our vow?"
"No. I swore I'd redeem you. And I will."
"I thought not." Mischa pointed his staff at a nearby mountain. "Meet me tomorrow on that summit. Let's settle our business at last."
{@b To be Continued...}

entries.name: The Brothers Part 9
entries: The mountain air burned with the smell of ion and sulfur. Scorch marks cut through the grass and the soil, and toppled trees lay burning near the cliff's edge.

Mischa stared down at Laszlo's body. His brother's armour was scorched black by magic, though the longsword he held still shone in the morning light. Laszlo had fought like a demon, impervious to pain and seemingly driven by will alone.
In the end, Mischa was forced to use his strongest spell, stopping time to buy him a moment to drive a poison dagger through a joint in Laszlo's armour. Only then did the warrior fall.
Mischa had won—he had fulfilled the requirement of lichdom. But he felt no victory. Only an unrelenting sickness, a black pit opening in his core.

He reached for brother's helm to take one last look, but the longsword sprang from Laszlo's hand. Mischa shrieked as the blade sizzled through the air, cutting through the phylactery around his neck and plunging deep into his chest.
He collapsed to the ground next to Laszlo's body form. Gasping, feeling his life drain away, he reached out for his brother's hand.
"Laszlo," he whispered, "you kept your promise, after all. Forgive me..."
Overhead, the sun rose in the sky, and a hawk's cry echoed throughout the mountain.
{@b To be Continued...}

entries.name: The Brothers Part 10
entries: "What do you want to do when we get to Castalore, Laszlo?"

The two teenagers kept pace with each other as they followed the dirt road through Raevo. Laszlo grinned at his brother. "I'll join the Order of Dawn and be a great knight. I'll wear armour and learn how to use a sword. Then I'll head south and kill all the vampires!"
Mischa nodded. "I'm sure the Order will take you. You're much stronger than me."
"They'll take you too if you ask!"
"No." Mischa gazed ahead. Beyond the trees, the seashore beckoned. "I want to study magic. There's a mage college in Castalore, I think."
"Magic?" Laszlo looked at him quizzically. "Why magic?"
"Because vampires fear it more than swords. One day, I'll be so powerful they'll fear me too." His eyes darkened. "Then they'll pay."
Laszlo was quiet for a moment, then said, "Mischa, does this mean we'll get separated?"
"I-I don't think so. At least I don't want us to."
"Me neither," Laszlo replied. "But...if that does happen..."
"Yeah?"
"I'll come find you. I'm your brother, Mischa. I promise, I'll always look out for you."
"I believe you, Laszlo."
The two brothers hurried on, racing to reach town before nightfall.
{@b The End}

data.name: Transformations
entries: Many creatures hunt the nights of Etharis. While many are twisted beasts of hatred born from darkness, some were not always so. The following ruleset provides characters the means to become grim monsters of the dark themselves. From dread-inducing werewolves to all-powerful liches, the following transformations are available to characters who meet the prerequisites.

While transformations make for great roleplay opportunities, at no point do they provide an acceptable excuse to hurt the enjoyment of other players at the table. If you want to create a conflict between two player characters, it's imperative that you discuss this with the table (and particularly your GM) first.

entries.name: Beginning a Transformation
entries: Individuals rarely choose to transform into beings of the night. Instead, they have it forced upon them. Foul curses, horrific experiments, and the diabolical machinations of fiends, vampires, and other dark agents are all examples of how a character might start a transformation. However, there are times when a character may wish to begin a transformation of their own volition. Perhaps they have succumbed to the lure of power, or they see it as the only way to achieve a greater goal.

Regardless, the first step in any transformation should be a discussion with your GM. Make your intentions clear, as the transformation may not be suitable for the setting or story your GM is running.

The next step in a transformation is to ensure you meet all the prerequisites of the transformation. There are 2 types of prerequisites: mechanical and roleplay prerequisites. Mechanical prerequisites can be ability score, spellcasting, and other feature requirements. Roleplay prerequisites are the in-game actions required by a character to start a transformation. It is recommended that this milestone be reached within the game rather than through a backstory. However, you may wish to discuss alternative avenues to pursue a prerequisite with your GM.

entries.name: A Blessing or a Curse?
entries: Within the dark fantasy world of Etharis, Transformations are representative of the gothic and body horror elements of the world. As a result, they should increase a character in power but ultimately be rooted in tragedy, as the setting demands. However, if you are not playing in a dark fantasy setting or you want your Transformation to feel more like a blessing than a curse, discuss with your GM the possibility of removing some or all the flaws associated with your Transformation. Alternatively, feel free to tinker with the boons and flaws with your GM. Transformations should suit the needs of your campaign, not the other way around.

entries.name: Boons and Flaws
entries: When you have achieved all the required prerequisites of a transformation and reached your first transformation level, you gain all the boons and the flaw of the first level. These constitute the beginning of the changes from the transformation. The boons and flaws of these iconic monsters come from folklore, pop culture, and our own imagination. If they differ from an existing trope or stat block, it is because they represent a variation unique to Etharis.

entries.name: Leveling Up
entries: Characters that have successfully completed a transformation can continue the process by increasing their transformation level. The character must achieve a milestone before gaining a transformation level. Each type of transformation has an example list of possible milestones that are thematically unique. Talk with your GM to come up with applicable milestones for your campaign and how you can achieve them.
When you increase your transformation level, you choose one boon from that level, or a lower level, provided you meet that boon's prerequisites. You gain the new level's flaw as well.

entries.name: Universal Milestones
entries: The following milestones are examples that can apply to all (or most) transformations:

items: Undertaking an exceptionally evil (or good) act
Completing an ancient ritual
Obtaining a powerful artifact
Being cursed by a dark agent
Being exalted by a patron or god

entries.name: Suggested Class Level to Transformation Level
entries: While transformations are milestone achievements and each level comes with a flaw, transformations still represent a significant increase in power. For this reason, it's recommended that players and GMs use the following level table as a guide for when players should be able to level up a transformation. After all, only the strongest survive such an ordeal. This table is a guide however, and cannot be applied to all Transformations equally. Transformations such as the Lich are much more powerful and should only be available at higher levels of play.
Not all transformations can follow these recommendations due to prerequisites. In this case, characters can reach higher transformation levels at higher class levels.

entries.name: Removing a Transformation
entries: Reversing a transformation is an incredibly difficult process. The changes that have occurred in a character have fundamentally altered their biology, and perhaps their mind. However, anything is possible in a magical world. To cure a transformation, treat it as a curse from the curses section. The curse level of a transformation is equal to the character's transformation level.

Rather than casting {@spell remove curse} with the cure components, the {@spell regenerate} spell must be cast with the cure components instead. A character that has reached the 4th level of a transformation, or that has been transformed for longer than one year, can only be cured by a {@spell wish} spell. If a character is killed and resurrected, the GM decides if they are resurrected with transformation levels.

entries.name: Additional Boons and Flaws
entries: The following Boons are new options for existing Transformations found in {@loader Grim Hollow: The Campaign Guide|book/Ghostfire Gaming; Grim Hollow Campaign Guide}.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Unearthly Senses
entries: Starting at 2nd level, you may use a bonus action to enhance your body's sensory organs, or grow entirely new ones. While this effect is active, you may choose one of the following Adaptations:

entries.name: Keen Senses
entries: Your eyes bulge, your skin tingles, and your nostrils flare. You gain advantage on Wisdom ({@skill Perception}) checks that rely on sight, hearing, or smell.

entries.name: Darkvision
entries: Your eyes take on the appearance of a cat's, growing to fill the upper half of your face. You can see in dim light within 60 feet of you as if it were bright light, and in darkness as if it were dim light. You can't discern color in darkness, only shades of gray. If you already possess darkvision from another source, the distance extends to 120 feet instead.

entries.name: Third Eye
entries: Another eye emerges from your forehead, granting you the ability to see invisible creatures and objects as if they were visible.

These Adaptations last until you become {@condition unconscious}, use a different one of these Adaptations, or use a bonus action on your turn to end the Adaptation. Once you reach Transformation Level 4, you may choose two of the listed Adaptations instead of one.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Shifting Form
entries: Your body has begun to lose its cohesion, softening and shifting like thick jelly. You take no extra damage from critical hits due to the shuffling of your internal organs. Whenever you make a melee or ranged attack using your Eldritch Limbs, you deal an additional {@dice 1d6} acid damage. You gain resistance to acid damage.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Amorphous Flesh
entries: {@note Prerequisite: Shifting Form}

Your body has continued to dissolve into a corrosive slurry of flesh and bone similar to an ooze. You are able to move through gaps as narrow as 1 inch wide, and you are immune to the grappled, prone, and restrained conditions.

In addition, whenever you take 10 or more points of bludgeoning, piercing, or slashing damage, you may choose to continue splitting along the wound, separating into two distinct parts that reform into versions of yourself that are one size smaller than the original, each with one half of your current hit points. If you have an odd number of hit points, you choose which segment gets the additional 1 hp. As you split you may choose how your armor and other equipment is split between the two.

On your turn you may move with each form and you may also take one action with each form. You may only take one bonus action and one reaction per turn, although you may choose which segment you want to act when you do so.

You may reform into a single body as an action, which may be taken by either segment when they are both within 5 feet of one another. If you do so, you regain hit points equal to the number of hit points your other form has, and you become your normal size. Your second body lasts for one hour before dissolving into nothingness.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Brand of the Slaver's Leash
entries: As an action, a flaming whip appears in your hand and lashes out at a creature you can see within 10 feet of you. That creature must make a Dexterity saving throw against your Transformation Save DC. On a failed save, the creature takes 2d4 fire damage and is inflicted with a searing brand.

While branded in this way, the creature is tied to you with a wreathing leash of flame and cannot use its movement to move more than 10 feet away from you. On your turn, you may use a bonus action to drag the creature up to 10 feet in any direction. You may also use your reaction to prevent any event that would take the creature out of range. For example, if the branded creature uses the {@spell misty step} spell to move out of the 10 feet radius, or an ally of the target attempting to physically drag their ally out of the leash's range, the attempt fails.
Spells that have the ability to teleport multiple people, like {@spell dimension door}, work as intended for all involved except for the branded creature.

A creature remains branded this way for 1 minute. The brand disappears if the creature is knocked {@condition unconscious}, enters hallowed ground, is targeted by the {@spell remove curse} spell, or if the creature is more than 10 feet away from you at the end of any turn.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Infernal Sub-Contractor
entries: Your mastery of the infernal laws allows you to utilize the benefits of two Gifts of Damnation simultaneously. In addition, you may change gifts on a short rest instead of a long rest.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Loophole
entries: As an expert in the magic of binding and the formation of magical contracts, you gain insight into the workings of summoning spells and how to interfere with them. Whenever you encounter a summoned creature, you are immediately aware it was summoned. As an action, you may wrest control of a summoning spell away from the caster. The spellcaster must make a Wisdom saving throw against your Transformation Save DC. On a failure, you gain control over the spell and any remaining creatures as if you had cast the spell, including concentration for any remaining duration. You may use this ability a number of times equal to your Charisma modifier (minimum 1), and you regain all uses of this ability when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Phylactery Bond
entries: You share an especially strong bond with your phylactery and gain benefits from keeping it on your person. You may choose to craft your phylactery into an amulet, a ring, a brooch, or some other form of jewelry. When you finish a short or long rest and you are wearing your phylactery, you may choose a damage type other than radiant damage. As long as you wear your phylactery, you have immunity to that damage type. In addition, your phylactery is more resilient than normal. Your phylactery's AC becomes 20 and its hit points increase to 120.
Your phylactery's nature is hidden from casual observation, and an observer must make an Intelligence ({@skill Arcana}) check against your Transformation Save DC in order to identify your phylactery.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Enhanced Phylactery
entries: {@note Prerequisite: Phylactery Bond}
Your bond with your phylactery strengthens, granting additional benefits:

items: If you aren't wearing armor, your base Armor Class is 15 + your Dexterity modifier. Your phylactery's AC is increased by 2.
Your spell save DC and spell attack bonus each increase by 2.
You and your phylactery have advantage on saving throws against spells and other magical effects.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Soul Reflection
entries: {@note Prerequisite: Enhanced Phylactery}

You have learned to utilize your bond with your phylactery to its greatest effect. While wearing your phylactery, whenever you are targeted by a spell, if you are the only target, you can use your reaction and spend charges from your phylactery equal to the spell's level. If you do so, the spell reflects and instead targets an appropriate target of your choice within range of the spell as if you cast it. For the purpose of using this feature, cantrips are considered 1st-level spells.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Heart of the Wild
entries: The spirits of nature speak to you through your bestial side, offering you guidance and knowledge. You may now cast and concentrate on spells in hybrid form. Additionally, you can speak, read, and write Sylvan, and you have advantage on Wisdom and Charisma checks to interact with fey and beasts.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Call the Pack
entries: {@note Prerequisite: Hunter's Howl}

When you use your Hunter's Howl ability, up to three allies you designate within 60 feet of the target also gain the benefits. Your Hunter's Howl also grants those allies advantage on attack rolls against the target if another affected ally is within 5 feet of the creature and not {@condition incapacitated}.
Additionally, when a hostile creature afflicted by your Hunters, Howl dies, you regain hit points equal to twice your Strength modifier.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Blood Frenzy
entries: {@note Prerequisite: Bestial Savagery}

Your bite attack damage increases to {@dice 2d8}. If you hit a creature with a bite attack, you can force the creature to make a Strength saving throw against your Transformation Save DC or be {@condition grappled}. While the target is {@condition grappled} in this way, you have advantage on attack rolls against them and deal additional damage with your natural weapons equal to your Strength modifier.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Divine Protection
entries: When you or an allied creature you can see within 30 feet is targeted by an attack, you can use your reaction to shield them with holy light. The target gains a +4 bonus to AC against the attack. You may use this feature a number of times equal to your Wisdom modifier (minimum of 1). You regain all uses of this feature when you finish a long rest.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Holy Bulwark
entries: You may use your action to steel yourself against the tactics of your most hated adversaries, gaining one of the following benefits:

entries.name: Stand Against the Infernal
entries: You gain resistance to fire damage.

entries.name: Cleanse the Undead
entries: You gain resistance to necrotic damage.

entries.name: Ignore Fey Trickery
entries: You are immune to {@condition charmed} and {@condition frightened} conditions.
This effect lasts until you use this feature again.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Aura of Celestial Resilience
entries: You emit an aura of stalwart conviction. This aura radiates up to 20 feet from you while you are conscious. When you or an ally within range of your aura fails a saving throw, they can choose to succeed it instead. Once a creature has benefited from this feature, they cannot benefit from it again until they have completed a long rest.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Night Stalker
entries: You gain proficiency in {@skill Stealth}. If you already have proficiency in {@skill Stealth}, then your proficiency bonus is doubled when making {@skill Stealth} ability checks. Additionally, you can attempt to hide even when you are only lightly obscured, including dim light.
You also gain a climb speed equal to your walking speed. You can climb difficult surfaces, including upside down on ceilings, without needing to make an ability check.

entries.name: Transformation Boon: Improved Shapechanger
entries: {@note Prerequisite: Shapechanger}
When you use your Shapechanger ability, you may also take on the form of a {@creature dire wolf}. While in dire wolf form you gain the following features:

Your movement speed changes to 50 feet. If you have sunlight hypersensitivity, it is reduced to sunlight sensitivity: while in sunlight, you have disadvantage on attack rolls and ability checks, but take no damage from direct contact with sunlight.
